article.body: The Republican governor of Maryland published a withering account of President Donald Trump's handling of the coronavirus pandemic on Thursday, outlining how the federal government failed to offer states support on testing and even added to their burden, and including this lament: “ âIâm a GOP governor. Why didnât Trump help my state with coronavirus testing?â ” â Gov. Larry Hogan of Maryland In an essay published in the Washington Post thatâs excerpted from a forthcoming book, Gov. Larry Hogan describes how he turned to his South Korean wife, Yumi, for help in procuring vital test kits from her home country by asking President Moon Jae-in to connect Maryland with LabGenomics, a medical testing company. Seoul sent Maryland a half-million tests at a cost of $9 million. âIt was a bargain considering the $2.8 billion in revenue we projected the pandemic would cost Maryland,â Hogan wrote. See: Hunt for medical supplies creates marketplace of desperation Even then, Maryland had to take extra precautions to secure the tests by driving them to a warehouse at an undisclosed location. That was after the federal government seized 3 million N95 masks purchased by Gov. Charlie Baker of Massachusetts, like Hogan a Republican governor of a typically âblueâ state. âWe werenât going to let Washington stop us from helping Marylanders,â said Hogan. The test-kit purchase was necessary after Hogan and other governors watched Trump consistently play down the threat of the virus, failing to âissue public warnings, draw up a 50-state strategy, or dispatch medical gear or lifesaving ventilators from the national stockpile to American hospitals.â âEventually, it was clear that waiting around for the president to run the nationâs response was hopeless; if we delayed any longer, weâd be condemning more of our citizens to suffering and death,â he wrote. Hogan recounted how Trump responded to news of the first U.S. case of COVID-19 while at Davos in January, immediately insisting during a friendly CNBC interview that it was âtotally under control.â The U.S. now has 3.49 million confirmed cases, and 137,420 people have died, according to data aggregated by Johns Hopkins University. âSo many nationwide actions could have been taken in those early days but werenât. While other countries were racing ahead with well-coordinated testing regimes, the Trump administration bungled the effort,â Hogan wrote. The first CDC test was faulty, and burdensome regulations delayed private U.S. labs from coming up with accurate tests. As Trump tweeted and told reporters that âanyone can have a test,â the reality on the ground was far different. âThe resulting disorganization would delay mass testing for almost two months and leave the nation largely in the dark as the epidemic spread,â Hogan wrote. There were dire forecasts, he noted: that the outbreak would become a catastrophe, that the death toll could be significant, that the coronavirus was much more contagious than SARS. âYou have to follow the science â thatâs where the answers lie,â the governor wrote. Other criticisms of Trump in the essay include his falsely blaming the Obama administration for the CDCâs faulty tests and his bragging that the U.S. was testing more than anybody in the world. âThis was true in absolute numbers, since we are a much bigger country, but weâd tested far fewer per capita than the Koreans had â 1,048 tests per million people vs. South Koreaâs 6,764 per million â and of course that was the only figure that mattered,â said Hogan.
